page.title: 06Ecology of the Area
page.content: Red deer and roe deer, inhabit the coniferous forest. Foxes, weasels, hedghogs, badgers inhabit the farmlands, along with rabbits, which are on the increase. There is a resurgence of the red squirrel in coniferous woods. Foxes are regarded as a great nuisance on the farms and there are 2 local hunts which cover the territory, the Percy and the West Percy. There are pheasant, partridge and curlew on grassland and moorland. The streams support small trout, mallard, dippers and herons (no report of kingfishers). In the SE corner of the block, there is a woodland area covering 88 acres called Birsley Wood. It is used by the Local Education Authority to show children a variety of flora and fauna and instruct them in conservation of the countryside.
